Title.evidence: Methods:: We performed a single-center randomized controlled trial.

Trial_Design.evidence: The required sample size was 120 patients.

Participants.evidence: Eligible patients were <65 years of age, working outside the home, and scheduled to undergo unicompartmental or total KA.

Intervention.evidence: Using GAS, patients developed personal activity goals with a physiotherapist preoperatively. Standard rehabilitation consisted of regular outpatient physiotherapy visits.

Objective.evidence: We hypothesized that, compared with standard rehabilitation, GAS-based rehabilitation would result in younger, active patients having higher satisfaction regarding activities after KA.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome measures were visual analogue scale (VAS) scores (scale of 0 to 100) for satisfaction regarding activities of daily living and work and leisure-time activities 1 year postoperatively.

Number_Randomised.evidence: The required sample size was 120 patients.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Patient satisfaction with work activities was significantly higher in the GAS group (Î² = 10.7 points, 98% confidence interval [CI] = 2.0 to 19.4 points) than in the control group.
